title: Would reading slowly help someone to write better? - Quora

response.answer_text: Reading in general is a crucial part of editing. So if you aren’t an effective reader, than your editing goes out the window. This has major major effects on your writing quality. If you read slowly, you become a better reader. Even though reading isn’t solely about speed, it more so depends on how well you understand what you’re reading. Reading slowly is a good way to do that rather than skimming and potentially missing key points. I used to skim everything I read just to get done with it. I didn’t take in the imagery, tone, setting, plot, etc. To be honest, that began to kill my love for reading. Then I’d try to edit my articles and I’d have a very hard time with it. My editing skills were basically fixing grammatical issues. There’s so much more to editing than that. Here is my new editing process since I started reading slower: Cut all unnecessary fluff (almost 1/3 of the article)Wait another dayCut all unnecessary fluff again (about 1/5 of the article)Run through grammar checkerRead aloudEver since I started reading slower, I can enjoy other people’s work more and properly edit my own. As I always say, editing requires you to be a student of the reader. To do that, you have to place yourself in the reader’s shoes. That means, taking in all the nuances of your writing. And that means, reading slower.

That doesn’t even make any sense. In order to write better it takes practice, being taught right from wrong and a purpose. Meaning when you start writing, you encourage yourself to develop the skill better through writing about things that interests you. How would literally reading slower help? Yes, you may be able to soak in the words, but that’s also a no at the same time. If you’re not interested in what you’re reading, then you’re less likely to give af about what words are stated infront of you. For example, I’d rather read a manga in comparison to a mystery novel. If I’m not interested in that specific manga, in comparison to the mystery novel….then I will soak in the mystery novels words more than manga. And the same vise versa.
